review.title: Compositional Learning of Relation Path Embedding for Knowledge Base Completion
review.abstract: Nowadays, large-scale knowledge bases containing billions of facts have reached impressive sizes; however, they are still far from completion. In addition, most existing methods only consider the direct links between entities, ignoring the vital impact about the semantic of relation paths. In this paper, we study the problem of how to better embed entities and relations into different low dimensional spaces. A compositional learning model of relation paths embedding (RPE) is proposed to take full advantage of additional semantic information expressed by relation paths. More specifically, using corresponding projection matrices, RPE can simultaneously embed entities into corresponding relation and path spaces. It is also suggested that type constraints could be extended from traditional relation-specific to the new proposed path-specific ones. Both of the two type constraints can be seamlessly incorporated into RPE and decrease the errors in prediction. Experiments are conducted on the benchmark datasets and the proposed model achieves significant and consistent improvements compared with the state-of-the-art algorithms for knowledge base completion.

metadata.title: Compositional Learning of Relation Path Embedding for Knowledge Base Completion

sections.heading: 2 Related Work
sections.text: First, we will focus on three classic translation-based models that consider only direct connections between entities: the lower case letter v denotes a column vector, and the upper case letter M denotes a matrix. The first translation-based model is TransE, and it defines the score function as S (h, r, t) = h + r − t for each triple (h, r, t). The score becomes smaller if the triple (h, r, bold) is correct; otherwise, the score will get higher. Embedding is achieved by optimizing a global margin loss function. This assumption is clearly simple and cannot well address more complex relationship attributes, i.e., N-to-1, and N-toN.

sections.heading: 3 Our Model
sections.text: Consistent semantics expressed by reliable relationship paths have a significant impact on meaningful embedding. Here, we propose a compositional learning model of relationship path embedding (RPE) that includes novel path-specific projection and type constraints. All units form the unit, and all relationships form the relationship. RPE uses PRA to select reliable relationship paths. Precisely, for a threefold (h, r, t), Pall = {p1, p2,...., pk} is the path specified for the entity pair (h, t). PRA calculates P (t | h, pi), the probability of reaching t from h according to the relationship sequence specified by pi, which can be recursively defined as follows: If pi is an empty path, P (t | h, pi), whose properties otherwise (1) end.

sections.heading: 3.1 Path-specific Projection
sections.text: The key idea of the RPE is that the consistent semantics of the reliable relation paths are similar to the semantics of the relationship between an entity pair. For a triple (h, r, t), RPE uses the dimensions of the relation paths Mr, Mp, Rm · n to the entity vectors h, t, Rn in the entity space into the corresponding relation paths and pathways simultaneously (m is the dimension of the relation paths, n is the dimension of the entity embedding, and m may differ from n. The projected vectors (hr, hp, tp, tp) in their respective embedding spaces are multiplied as follows: hr = Mrh, hp = Mph (3) tp = Mpt (4) Because relation paths are these sequences of relations p = (r1, r2, rm).

sections.heading: 3.2 Path-specific Type Constraints
sections.text: In RPE, based on the semantic similarity between relationships and reliable relationship pathways, we can, of course, extend the relationship-specific type constraints to novel path-specific type constraints. In type-bound TransE, the distribution of corrupt triples is a uniform distribution. In our model, we borrow the idea of TransH by including the two type constraints with a Bernoulli distribution. For each relationship r, we denote the domainr and ranger, around the subject and object types of the relationship r.Domainr is set the entity whose entities coincide with Domainr, and "Ranger" is set the entity whose entities coincide with rangers. We calculate the average numbers of the tail entities called teh, and the average numbers of the tail entities for each tail element called Het. The Bernoulli distribution with the parameter tehh is probable.

sections.heading: 3.3 Training Details
sections.text: The score function of RPE (initial) is as follows: G (h, r, t) = S (h, r, t) + λ · S (h, p, t) = Ăh + r − t, pi, pi) · Pr (r, pi) · h + p, t (11) This score function is also used as a baseline in our experiment. − The projection matrices Ms are initialized as identity matrices. − RPE holds the local closed world assumption (LCWA) [Dong et al., 2014], where each relationship corrects its domain and range types at the instance level. − Your type information is provided by KBs or the entities represented in observed tripartite relationships. Note that each relationship is required for the inverse relationship to the inverse.

sections.heading: 4 Experiments
sections.text: In order to investigate the retrievability and discrimination of our model, the RPE is evaluated against two standard completion tasks: link prediction and triple classification. In addition, we present a case study on consistent semantics learned through our method to further emphasize the importance of relationship paths for learning knowledge representation.

sections.heading: 4.1 Datasets
sections.text: We evaluate our model using two classic large knowledge bases: Freebase and WordNet. Freebase is a large shared knowledge base that contains billions of facts about the real world, such as the triple database (Beijing, Locatedin, China), which describes the fact that Beijing is located in China. WordNet is a large lexical knowledge base of English, in which each unit expresses a different concept, and each relationship is a conceptual-semantic or lexical relationship. We use two subsets of the freebase, FB15K and FB13 [Bordes et al., 2013] and a subset of WordNet, WN11 [Socher et al., 2013]. Table 1 presents the statistics of the data sets, with each column representing the numbers of the entity type, the relationship type and the triplets divided into education, validation and test sets.

sections.heading: 4.2 Link Prediction
sections.text: The task of the link prediction consists of predicting the possible h or t for test triples if h or t is overlooked. FB15K is used for this task.

sections.heading: Evaluation Protocol
sections.text: We follow the same evaluation procedures as in [Bordes et al., 2013; Wang et al., 2014; Lin et al., 2015b]. Firstly, we replace each test triple (h, r, t) h or t with each entity in the database. Secondly, each corrupt triple is calculated by the corresponding score function S (h, r, t). The final step is to rank the original correct entity with these scores in descending order. Note that if a corrupt triple already exists in the knowledge base, it should not be considered false. We prefer to remove these corrupt triples from our data set and call this setting "filters." If these corrupt triples already exist in the knowledge base, it should not be considered false. We prefer to remove these corrupt triples from our data set and call this setting "filters." If these corrupt triples are used in the knowledge base, "then we reserve the results for the better ones in the two.

sections.heading: Implementation
sections.text: We set the dimension of embedding units and relations n below {20, 50, 100, 120}, the margin γ1 below {1, 2, 3, 4, 5}, the margin γ2 below {3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8}, the learning rate α for SGD below {0.01, 0.005, 0.0025, 0.001, 0.0001}, the batch size B below {20, 120, 480, 960, 1440, 4800} and the equilibrium factor λ below {0.5, 0.8, 1.1.5, 2}. The thresholds are in the range of {0.01, 0.02, 0.04, 0.05} to reduce the calculation of meaningless paths. For determining the optimal parameters, the grid search is used. The best configurations for RPE (ACOM) are n = 100, m = 100, γ1 = 2, γ2 = 5, α = 0.0001, B = 4800, and installation = 0.05 (we choose the starting point for the LPE).

sections.heading: Analysis of Results
sections.text: Table 2 reports on the results of the link prognosis, in which the first column is translation-based models, the variants of PTransE and our models. Obesity figures are the best performance, and n-hop shows the path length n that PTransE uses. We designate RPE only with path-specific limitations such as RPE (PC), and from the results we can observe the following: 1) Our models exceed the classical knowledge of embedding models (TransE, TransR, and FB15K with the metrics of the middle rank and hits @ 10 (filters).

sections.heading: 4.3 Triple Classification
sections.text: We perform the triple classification using three benchmark data sets: FB15K, FB13 and WN11. The triple classification aims to predict whether a given triple (h, r, t) is correct, which is a problem of binary classification.

sections.heading: Evaluation Protocol
sections.text: To accomplish this task, we set different relative thresholds: In a triple test (h, r, t), if its score S (h, r, t) is below δr, we predict a positive value, otherwise a negative one. {δr} is obtained by maximizing the accuracy of classification on the valid set.

sections.heading: Implementation
sections.text: Since [Lin et al., 2015a] does not evaluate the performance of PTransE in this task, we use the code of PTransE released in [Lin et al., 2015a] to complete it. FB13 and WN11 already contain negative samples. For FB15K, we use the same method to produce negative samples as suggested by [Socher et al., 2013]. Hyperparameter intervals are the same as link predictions. The best configurations for RPE (PC + ACOM) are as follows: n = 50, m = 50, γ1 = 5, γ2 = 6, α = 0.0001, B = 1440, λ = 0.8, and η = 0.05, taking the L1 standard on WN11; n = 100, γ1 = 3, γ1 = 1 = 0.00001, and we take 0.001 = Profile.

sections.heading: Analysis of Results
sections.text: Results show that 1) RPE (PC + ACOM) performs best on all datasets, making good use of path-specific projection and type constraints; 2) RPE (PC) improves performance of RPE (initial) by 4.5%, 6.0% and 13.2%, especially on FB15K; therefore, we consider the lengthening of distances for similar units in the embedding space to be essential for specific problems. The results of the experiments also suggest that although LCWA can compensate for the loss of type information, real relation type information prevails.

sections.heading: 4.4 Case Study of Consistent Semantics
sections.text: As shown in Table 5, for two pairs of entities (Sociology, George Washington University) and (Planet of the Apes, Art Director) of Freebase, RPE provides two relations and four most relevant relationship paths (each relationship is mapped to two relation paths, referred to as a and b), which are considered to be similar semantics to their respective relationships. However, this type of consistent semantics of reliable relation paths cannot be achieved by translation-based models such as Trans (E, H, R), since translation-based models only utilize the direct links and do not take into account relationship paths, such as reliable relation paths in lines 3 and 6 of Table 5. In contrast, RPE can achieve reliable relation paths with its consistent semantics and expands the projection and type limitations of the specific relation to the specific path. Furthermore, the experimental results show that RPE exceeds the level of knowledge and type limitations in the two additional semantics by using benchmarks.

sections.heading: 5 Conclusions and Future Work
sections.text: In this paper, we propose a compositional learning model of the Relationship Path Embedding (RPE) to complete the knowledge base. To our knowledge, this is the first time that a path-specific projection has been proposed, and it simultaneously embeds each unit in relation and path spaces to learn more meaningful embedding. In addition, we also present the novel path-specific type constraints based on relation-specific constraints to better distinguish similar embedding in latent space. In the future, we plan to include 1) other potential semantic information in the modeling of the relationship path, such as the information provided by these intermediate nodes linked by relation paths, and 2) the relationship path in other applications related to knowledge bases, such as remote monitoring for the extraction of relationships and answering questions about knowledge bases.

, 2013], and language modeling [Ahn et al., 2016].
Traditional KB completion approaches, such as Markov logic networks [Richardson and Domingos, 2006], suffer from feature sparsity and low efficiency.

Among these methods, TransE [Bordes et al., 2013] is a classical neural-based model, which assumes that each relation can be regarded as a translation from head to tail and uses a score function S(h,r,t)=‖h+ r − t‖ to measure the plausibility for triples.
TransH [Wang et al., 2014] and TransR [Lin et al.
, 2014] and TransR [Lin et al., 2015b] are representative variants of TransE.
Consequently, a promising new research direction is to use relation paths to learn knowledge embeddings [Neelakantan et al., 2015; Guu et al., 2015; Toutanova et al., 2016].

However, the consistent semantics expressed by some relation paths p is unreliable for reasoning new facts of that entity pair [Lin et al., 2015a].
As the path ranking algorithm (PRA) [Lao et al., 2011] suggests, relation paths that end in many possible tail entities are more likely to be unreliable for the entity pair.

Another research direction focuses on improving the prediction performance by using prior knowledge in the form of relation-specific type constraints [Krompass et al., 2015; Chang et al., 2014; Wang et al., 2015].

metadata.abstractText: Large-scale knowledge bases have currently reached impressive sizes; however, these knowledge bases are still far from complete. In addition, most of the existing methods for knowledge base completion only consider the direct links between entities, ignoring the vital impact of the consistent semantics of relation paths. In this paper, we study the problem of how to better embed entities and relations of knowledge bases into different low-dimensional spaces by taking full advantage of the additional semantics of relation paths, and we propose a compositional learning model of relation path embedding (RPE). Specifically, with the corresponding relation and path projections, RPE can simultaneously embed each entity into two types of latent spaces. It is also proposed that type constraints could be extended from traditional relation-specific constraints to the new proposed path-specific constraints. The results of experiments show that the proposed model achieves significant and consistent improvements compared with the state-of-the-art algorithms.
